Context:
The Human Services Foundations (A113) program is a certificate program offered by George Brown College that focuses on the study of human behavior with a concentration on psychology, sociology, and anti-oppressive practice. This foundation establishes an essential base for success in both the classroom and human services sector. Students will develop teamwork skills through collaborative activities, learning effective communication and forming positive working relationships in diverse and inclusive team environments.

Key learnings from this program include:
- Thinking critically by applying communication and research skills to present information factually
- Identifying systemic barriers impacting equity and inclusion in Canadian society
- Understanding the role human services professionals play in removing these barriers
- Exploring various career pathway options within the human services sector
- Making informed decisions about future academic and professional goals
- Acquiring academic and life skills, such as self-awareness and strategies for wellness, lifelong learning, and self-development.

George Brown College offers several supports to help students achieve their academic and career objectives:
1. Student Success Counselor: Individual access to a counselor who designs solutions for college challenges.
2. Pathway Advisor: Assistance in discussing specific academic and career goals, exploring potential pathway opportunities.
3. Peer Learning Group: Weekly group facilitated by former graduates for support on course content and program assignments.
4. Career & Postgraduate Study Opportunities: Explore further study options and career paths within human services sector upon completion of A113.

For more information on related programs, visit the "Career and Postgraduate Study Opportunities" tab on the left side of the page.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Human Services Foundations Program A113 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Programs and Required Courses for Human Services Foundations (A113) graduates:
- American Sign Language and Deaf Studies (C114)
- Assaulted Women’s and Children’s Counsellor/Advocate (C137)
- Behavioural Science Technician (C146)
- Child and Youth Care (C133)
- Community Worker (C101)
- Deafblind & Intervenor Studies (C158)
- Early Childhood Education (C100)
- Recreation Management in Gerontology (C152)
- Social Service Worker (C119)

Exemptions for Human Services Foundations (A113) graduates:
- Exempt from repeating College English (COMM 1007)
- Exempt from one General Education Elective (GNED) course

Contact Information:
- Pathway Advisor: georgebrown.ca/preparation, ext. 6298 or kkieley@georgebrown.college

Programs with Limited Seats and No Guaranteed Admission:
- American Sign Language and Deaf Studies (C114)
- Assaulted Women’s and Children’s Counsellor/Advocate (C137)
- Behavioural Science Technician (C146)
- Child and Youth Care (C133)
- Community Worker (C101)
- Deafblind & Intervenor Studies (C158)
- Early Childhood Education (C100)
- Recreation Management in Gerontology (C152)
- Social Service Worker (C119)

Required Courses for Human Services Foundations Program:
- Semester 1: CARE 1083, HUMAN SERVICES OVERVIEW; PSY 1083, FOUNDATIONS OF PSYCHOLOGY 1; COUN 1007, GROUP PROCESS; COMM 1000, INTRODUCTION TO COLLEGE COMMUNICATION; PREP 1017, PERSONAL AND CAREER DEVELOPMENT
- Semester 2: COMM 2000, COMMUNICATING ACROSS CONTEXTS; PSY 1084, FOUNDATIONS OF PSYCHOLOGY 2; PREP 1009, INTRODUCTION TO RESEARCH; PREP 1025, SPEAKING WITH CONFIDENCE; GSSC1064, ABLEISM, MENTAL HEALTH & OPPRESSION: SOCIOLOGICAL PERPECTIVES; SWRK1075, MINDFULNESS & WELLBEING; SWRK1076, THRIVING IN RELATIONSHIPS; GNED, GENERAL EDUCATION ELECTIVE
- General Education Electives: Students are required to take one General Education Elective.

Additional Information and Support Services:
- Access to a Pathway Advisor for information about upgrading options, pre-programs, and articulation agreements, as well as assistance with transitioning into further post-secondary programs.
- Access to a Student Success Specialist for academic and career goal assistance, general and personalized success strategies, peer learning groups, and college-wide resources.

Context:
Program Name: Human Services Foundations (A113)
Contact Information: Katie Kieley, ext. 6298 or kkieley@georgebrown.ca
Course Outlines and Articulation Agreement available
Program Learning Outcomes:
- Discuss roles, responsibilities, career opportunities in Community Services and Child Studies field
- Apply culturally sensitive communication skills
- Explain major theoretical models of behaviour associated with psychology
- Use appropriate client service strategies
- Select best suited Community Services and Child Studies field
- Understand how academic strengths, needs and personal health factors affect success and wellness in college environment
- Utilize written and verbal communication skills specific to the field
Tuition & Fees:
Domestic Students: $3,767.00 for first two semesters (Fall 2022)
International Students: $17,419.00 (estimated) for first two semesters (Fall 2023)
Financial Assistance: Approved for OSAP funding (meets eligibility criteria)
Admission Requirements: Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Human Services Foundations Program A113 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
* Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent is required for application.
* Grade 12 English with a minimum grade of C or U is necessary.
* Mature students (19 years old and above without an OSSD) can take the Admissions Assessment for English or consider upgrading to get required English credits.
* College or university credits may qualify for course exemptions, more information can be found on the transfer guide.
* International Students should visit the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, international students should apply through George Brown College Online Application System.
* Contact Preparation Advisor at 416-415-5000 ext. 2562 or email preparation@georgebrown.ca for information on college and work preparation programs.
* Human Services Foundations Program Co-ordinator can be reached at abooth@georgebrown.ca.
* Contact Center can be contacted at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
* International recruitment representatives can be reached by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry.
* Pre-Community Services program is taught at St. James Campus at 341 King St. E., Toronto, Ontario.
* Related programs include Social Service Worker (C119), Community Worker (C101), and Social Service Worker (Accelerated) (C135).
* Andre Luiz Santos shared his experience as a newcomer and international student at George Brown College, expressing confidence gained through support from professors, classmates, and institution services.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Human Services Foundations Program A113 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: Andre Luiz Santos Carvalho holds an Ontario College Certificate from George Brown College. The college offers campus tours that can be booked through their website. Interested applicants are required to provide their first name, last name, email address, and indicate whether they are domestic or international students along with their country of origin. They need to agree to receive email communications from the college and understand their right to unsubscribe at any time. The form cannot be used without enabling JavaScript.
